questions.question_text:
Consider the reaction :


Cl2(aq) + H2S(aq) → S(s) + 2H+ (aq) + 2Cl– (aq)


The rate equation for this reaction is rate = k [Cl2] [H2S]


Which of these mechanisms is/are consistent with this rate equation?

(A) Cl2 + H2S $$\to$$ H+ + Cl– + Cl+ + HS– (slow)


Cl+ + HS– $$\to$$ H+ + Cl– + S (fast) 

(B) H2S $$ \Leftrightarrow $$ H+ + HS– (fast equilibrium) 


Cl2 + HS– $$\to$$ 2Cl– + H+ + S (slow)
questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.question:
Consider the reaction :
Cl_{2}(aq) + H_{2}S(aq) → S(s) + 2H^{+} (aq) + 2Cl^{–} (aq)
The rate equation for this reaction is rate = k [Cl_{2}] [H_{2}S]
Which of these mechanisms is/are consistent with this rate equation?
(A) Cl_{2} + H_{2}S $$\to$$ H^{+} + Cl^{–} + Cl^{+} + HS^{–} (slow)
Cl^{+} + HS^{–} $$\to$$ H^{+} + Cl^{–} + S (fast) 
(B) H_{2}S $$ \Leftrightarrow $$ H^{+} + HS^{–} (fast equilibrium) 
Cl_{2} + HS^{–} $$\to$$ 2Cl^{–} + H^{+} + S (slow)

Statement - 2:  If the four chosen numbers form an AP, then the set of all possible values of common difference is $$\left( { \pm 1, \pm 2, \pm 3, \pm 4, \pm 5} \right).$$

options.D: Statement - 1 is true, Statement - 2 is true; Statement - 2 is a correct explanation for Statement - 1.

The speed of light in the medium is
questions.subject: Physics

options.B: the same everywhere in the beam
options.D: maximum on the axis of the beam

questions.question_text:
Statement - 1 :  Two particles moving in the same direction do not lose all their energy in a completely inelastic collision. 


Statement - 2 : Principle of conservation of momentum holds true for all kinds of collisions.
questions.subject: Physics

options.A: Statement - 1 is true, Statement - 2 is true; Statement - 2 is the correct explanation of Statement -  1
options.B: Statement - 1 is true, Statement - 2 is true; Statement - 2 is not the correct explanation of Statement -  1
options.C: Statement - 1 is false, Statement - 2 is true
options.D: Statement - 1 is true, Statement - 2 is false

Statement - 2 : Principle of conservation of momentum holds true for all kinds of collisions.
